notesStmt.note: Reproductions of the originals in the British Library (Yhomason Tracts) and the Goldsmiths'-Kress library of economic literature.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: The Account of John Bentley Surveyor and Woodward of all the Kings and Queenes MajeÅ¿ties ForreÅ¿ts, ChaÅ¿es, Parkes, Mannors and Lands, within the Counties of Kent, SuÅ¿Å¿ex, Surry, HampÅ¿hire, Berks, and MiddleÅ¿ex, and by authority from the right Honourable the Committee of Lords and Commons for His MajeÅ¿ties Revenue Å¿itting at WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter, of all Woods, Timber and Trees, felled and Å¿old, within the limits aforeÅ¿aid, by Order or warrant from the Å¿aid Honourable Committee, either Å¿everally by himÅ¿elfe or jointly with any other betweene MidÅ¿ummer 1644. and MidÅ¿umer 1648.
div.p:
SIr Tho. WilÅ¿ingham never felled or cauÅ¿ed to be felled any timber in the manner of Eltham, or in any of the parkes there, but what hath been felled, hath been felled by
me according to Order of the Committee of the Mannor.

Imprimis by Order from the Å¿aid honourable Committee bearing date 8 of Novem. 1644 made unto Sir Tho. WalÅ¿ingham Knight and the Å¿aid accountant, was Å¿old unto Tho. FoÅ¿ter of Mottingham in the County of Kent, and Thomas Wiley of Eltham in the Å¿aid County Yeoman, forty nine Acres of Coppice wood, lying within the Mannor o â¢
Eltham, viz. One Coppice called by the name of HaÅ¿ell wood, and parcell of two other Coppices neer thereunto, called by the name of Shephards Leaye, and Oxe Leaye, containing together, the Å¿aid quantity of 49 Acres Å¿tatute meaÅ¿ure, after the rate and price of 3li. per Acre, five Acres of the Å¿aid forty and nine, being allowed them without price, in lew and reÅ¿pect of div â¢ rs waÅ¿ts and Å¿poyles made therein by the poor people in thoÅ¿e parts, and certaine Lanes and Cart pathes therein, which did amount unto the Å¿um of 132li.

Of which Å¿um there was paid unto Tho. Fawconbridge EÅ¿q; receiver Generall for His MajeÅ¿ties revenue at WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter, on the Å¿ixt
day of Decem. 1644 According to the Å¿aid Order, the Å¿um of 80li.
And the remainder thereof was paid unto him on the 14 day of Sept. 1645 being 52li.

Item by one other Order from the Å¿aid honourable Committee bearing date 25th day of Sept, 1645 made unto the Å¿aid Sir Thomas WalÅ¿ingham and the Å¿aid accountant, was Å¿old unto the Å¿aid Thomas FoÅ¿ter, and Thomas Wiley, the remainder of Shephards Leaye, and Oxe Leaye, which being Å¿ince meaÅ¿ured, did amount to 88 Acres, at the rate and price of fifty Å¿hillings per Acre, at 18 foote pole, and came at the price aforeÅ¿aid to the Å¿umme of. 220li.

Whereof paid to the Å¿aid receiver Gen â¢ r â¢ ll on the 24th of March 1645 the Å¿um of 6 â¢
li.
And on the 14th Novem. 1645 the Å¿um of, 50li.

And on or about the 24 day of June
â¢ 6 â¢ 8 the Å¿um of, â¢ 0
â¢ i.
DisburÅ¿t by the Å¿aid accountant for the Coppices before named containing, Rods as by the workemens bills may appear the Å¿um of 7li. 2s. 2d.
Remaining in the Å¿aid accountant hands the Å¿um of 2li. 17s. 10.

Item, by the like Order from the Å¿aid honourable Committee bearing date 7 day of Decemb. 1644. made unto the Å¿aid Sir Thomas WalÅ¿ingham, and the Å¿aid Accompt was Å¿old unto one Richard EaÅ¿t of Lambeth, one Coppice or Spring of Oake and AÅ¿pe, containing about twenty Å¿ix Acres, being within Horne Parke, alias Lee Parke, in the Mannor of Eltham aforeÅ¿aid, for the Å¿umme of 220li.
Whereof paid unto the Receiver Generall on the 13. day of March 1644. the Å¿umme of 100li.
And on the 21 day of Septem. following the Å¿umme of 120li.

Item, by the before mentioned Order of the 25 of September 1645, was Å¿old unto the aforeÅ¿aid Richard EaÅ¿t, and one David Powell a Fletcher in GrubÅ¿treet London, one other Coppice of Oake and AÅ¿pe in Horne Parke aforeÅ¿aid after the rate and price of ten pound per Acre, which did containe ãâã Acres, and doth amount to the Å¿umme of 100li.
And the Å¿aid David Powel became bound to the Å¿aid Receiver Generall, as part thereof for the payment of 40 li.
Paid unto the Receiver Generall on the ninth day of Janu. 1645. the Å¿umme of 40 li.
Received of them Å¿ince by the Å¿aid Accomptant, 60 li.
The charges of fencing of the Å¿aid Coppice, was by the Å¿aid Order to bee defraied out of money ariÅ¿ing thereby; and there was disburÅ¿ed as followeth:
Unto John Spicer Carpenter for the rayling in thereof, containing a 130 Rods, with gates for the Å¿ame, at 20 d. per Rod, as by his Acquittance appeares, 10li. 16s. 8d.
Unto Thomas Glyn for the carriage of Å¿tuffe, and for the ditching and hedging thereof, and for Iron worke for the Å¿ame, the Å¿umme of 7li. 15s.

More paid unto Thomas Glyn on the 28 of June 1648, for and towards the new repaying and repleniÅ¿hing of the hedges and ditches of the two Coppices in Horne Park, formerly fenced, but Å¿ince broken downe by the Deere, and therefore of neceÅ¿Å¿ity to be
againe repaired the Å¿umme of 3li.
Remaining in the Å¿aid Accomptant hands the Å¿umme of 18li. 8s. 4d
The totall of all the wood Å¿ales within the Mannor aforeÅ¿aid, and time limited as aforeÅ¿aid, doe amount unto the Å¿umme of 602li.
Whereof paid in to the receipt as aforeÅ¿aid, the Å¿umme of 602li.
Due, and owing by David Powell, Fletcher, as aforeÅ¿aid, the Å¿umme of 20li.
DisburÅ¿ed for the fencing of the Å¿aid woods as aforeÅ¿aid, the Å¿umme of 28li. 13s. 10d
Remaining in the Å¿aid Accomptant hands the Å¿umme of 21li. 6s. 2d.
